titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Bernard and Katherine Read Papers
titlestmt.author: Compiled by Elizabeth Pipes and Martha Lund Smalley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Monday March 25, 2019 at 22:25

did.abstract: These papers document Bernard Read's work as a scientist in China from 1909 to 1949, as well as the life of his family in China and his internment during the Japanese occupation of Shanghai, 1941-1945. Bernard Read was not directly engaged by a missionary agency but spent the first part of his career in China at the Peking Union Medical College, a union venture related to various mission agencies. Read left the Peking Union Medical College due to disagreements with its leaders, and went to work for the Henry Lester Institute, an organization financed by an American businessman in Shanghai.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Bernard and Katherine Read Papers (RG 157), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library.

chronitem.event: Lecturer in Chemistry and Pharmacy, Peking Union Medical College
Johns Hopkins Medical School, Biochemistry, with summer classes at Chicago University and Harvard
Associate Professor of Biochemistry and Pharmacology, Peking
Head of Physiological Sciences, Henry Lester Institute of Medical Research, Shanghai
King Gold Medal, Peking Natural History Society
Interned by Japanese during WW II
Chairman, Canadian Aid to China and Nursing Aid Committee, China
Member of Union Community Church, Shanghai

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The bulk of this collection relates to Bernard Read's scientific research and writing regarding pharmacology. A full listing of titles of his writings is in the first folder of Series 3. Added to the collection in 2014 was an unpublished typescript manuscript by Read titled "Vegetable and Plant Drugs."

Extensive correspondence of Read records his interactions with colleagues in China and elsewhere. The collection also provides valuable documentation from the period when Read was interned by the Japanese during World War II. Also of interest is the correspondence from Katherine L. Read to her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Albert Henderson, who were missionaries in Burma, and correspondence between Katherine and Bernard during their separation caused by World War II.

The collection includes a biography of Bernard Read written by his wife and son, and an annotated copy of a memoir written by Katherine L. Read with Robert O. Ballou, which documents the work of her parents, Albert and Cora Henderson.

Added in 2014 were more than 500 3" x 3" glass slides accompanied by a listing of identification by number. The slides include plant, insect, and animal specimens, microscope slides of chemical compounds, archaeological sites in China, scientific equipment, individuals, class groups, scenes in China.

list.item: III. Writings of Bernard E. Read, 1917-1949, n.d.
IV. Personal Items and Memorabilia, 1919-1951, n.d.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An unpublished typescript manuscript by Read, taken from "Bencao gangmu" the late 16th century "Index of Native Herbs," a materia medica listing herbal drugs and their applications.

did.unittitle: "Golden Days in China" - biography of Bernard Read, by Katherine L. Read and Robert E. Read
Annotated copy of Bamboo Hospital: the Story of a Missionary Family in Burma by Katherine L. Read with Robert O. Ballou.
Official Condolences upon death of BER
Memoir of George E. Read (BER's father)
Yu Wang Fu and Old China Hands addresses

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: More than 500 3" x 3" glass slides are accompanied by a listing of identification by number. The slides include plant, insect, and animal specimens, microscope slides of chemical compounds, archaeological sites in China, scientific equipment, individuals, class groups, scenes in China.
